Minimizer & Maximizer

Local & Global Minimizer and Maximizer, Critical points

Mathematics

template

Author

Kwangmin Kim

Published

March 23, 2023

    • A minimizer or a maximizer refer to a point in the domain of a function where the function achieves its minimum or maximum value. More formally, let \(f: X → \mathbb R\) be a real-valued function defined on a set \(X \subset \mathbb R\).

    Definition 1 \(f(x^*)\) with a point \(x^* \in X\) is called a minimum if \(f(x^*) \le f(x)\) for all \(x \in X\). \[ \min_{x\in X}{f(x)} \] , which means a minimum, \(f(x)\).

    Definition 2 \(f(x^*)\) with a point \(x^* \in X\) is called a maximum if \(f(x^*) \ge f(x)\) for all \(x \in X\). \[ \max_{x\in X}{f(x)} \] , which means a maximum, \(f(x)\).

    Definition 3 A point \(x^* \in X\) is called a minimizer of \(f\) if \(f(x^*) \le f(x)\) for all \(x \in X\). \[ \arg\min_{x\in X}{f(x)} \] , which means \(x\) that mainimizes \(f(x)\).

    Definition 4 A point \(x^* \in X\) is called a maximizer of \(f\) if \(f(x^*) \ge f(x)\) for all \(x \in X\). \[ \arg\max_{x\in X}{f(x)} \] , which means \(x\) that maximizes \(f(x)\).

    Definition 5 A point \(x^* \in X\) is called a global mainimizer of \(f\) if \(f(x^*) \ge f(x)\) for all \(x \in \mathbb R\). \[ \arg\min_{x\in \mathbb R}{f(x)} \] , which means \(x\) that minimizes \(f(x)\).

    Definition 6 A point \(x^* \in X\) is called a global maximizer of \(f\) if \(f(x^*) \ge f(x)\) for all \(x \in \mathbb R\). \[ \arg\max_{x\in \mathbb R}{f(x)} \] , which means \(x\) that maximizes \(f(x)\).

    Definition 7 A point \(x^* \in X\) is called a strict global maximizer of \(f\)
    if \(f(x^*) > f(x)\) for all \(x \in \mathbb R\).

    Definition 8 A point \(x^* \in X\) is called a strict global miniimizer of \(f\)
    if \(f(x^*) < f(x)\) for all \(x \in \mathbb R\).

    Definition 9 A local minimizer of \(f\) is a point \(x* \in X\) such that there exists a radius, \(\delta>0\) of a neighborhood of \(x^*\) such that \(f(x*) \le f(x)\) for all \(x \in (x^*-\delta,x^*+\delta)\) or \(|x-x^*|<\delta\) . A local minimizer is at least best possible solution among nearby points.

    Definition 10 A local maximizer of \(f\) is a point \(x* \in X\) such that there exists a radius, \(\delta>0\) of a neighborhood of \(x^*\) such that \(f(x*) \ge f(x)\) for all \(x \in (x^*-\delta,x^*+\delta)\) or \(|x-x^*|<\delta\) . A local maximizer is at least best possible solution among nearby points.

    Definition 11 A strict local minimizer of \(f\) is a point \(x* \in X\) such that there exists a radius, \(\delta>0\) of a neighborhood of \(x^*\) such that \(f(x*) < f(x)\) for all \(x \in (x^*-\delta,x^*+\delta)\) or \(|x-x^*|<\delta\) . A local minimizer is at least best possible solution among nearby points.

    Definition 12 A strict local maximizer of \(f\) is a point \(x* \in X\) such that there exists a radius, \(\delta>0\) of a neighborhood of \(x^*\) such that \(f(x*) > f(x)\) for all \(x \in (x^*-\delta,x^*+\delta)\) or \(|x-x^*|<\delta\) . A local maximizer is at least best possible solution among nearby points.

    Definition 13 It is said to be a critical point if \(f'(x)\) exists and \(f'(x^*)=0\) for \(x^* \in X\).

    Note that a function may have multiple minimizers, and some functions may not have a minimizer at all. In addition, if a function has multiple minimizers, they may be either global or local minimizers.

    • Example
      • If \(f(x)=2(x-3)^2+8\), the vertex is \((2,8)\), the global minimizer is \(2\), the global minimum is \(8\).
      • If \(f(x)=x^3-3x^2+4\), then \(f'(x)=3x^2-6x=3x(x-2)\) and the critical points are \((0,4), (2,0)\)
      • If \(f(x)=7x^5-35x+4\), then \(f'(x)=35x^4-35=35(x^2+1)(x-1)(x+1)\) critical points are \((-1,0), (1,32)\)
      • If \(f(x)=\frac{2x}{x^2+1}\), then \(f'(x)=\frac{2(1-x)(1+x)}{(1+x^2)^2}\) the critical points are \((-1,-1), (1,1)\).

    Theorem 1 For \(f:X \rightarrow \mathbb R\), let \(f(x)\), \(f'(x)\), and \(f''(x)\) be all continuous. For \(x^* \in X\), \(f'(x^*)=0\)

    1. If \(f''(x)\ge 0\) for all \(x \in X\), \(x^*\) is a global minimizer
    2. If \(f''(x)> 0\) for all \(x \in X\), \(x^*\) is a strict global minimizer
    3. If \(f''(x^*)> 0\), \(x^*\) is a strict local minimizer

    the reverse of the stament 1 in Theorem 1 is not true.
